Then $B_\xi \in U_\xi.$ Also for $\zeta < \xi < \eta$ and $x \in B_\xi$ let $j^{\zeta}_{\xi,x}=j_{\bar{U}^{\zeta}_{\xi,x}}$, and assume
$K^{\zeta}_{\xi,x}$ is such that $K_\zeta = [x \mapsto K^{\zeta}_{\xi,x}]_{U_\xi}$. Then
$K^{\zeta}_{\xi,x}$ is ${\operatorname{Col}}((\kappa_x)_*^{++}, < j^{\zeta}_{\xi,x}(\kappa_x))_{N^{\zeta}_{\xi,x}}$-generic
over $N^{\zeta}_{\xi,x},$ where  $N^{\zeta}_{\xi,x}=Ult(V, \bar{U}^{\zeta}_{\xi,x})$.


We are now ready to define our main forcing notion. The forcing is essentially the same as the forcing construction in section 3.2 of \cite{sinapova}.
\begin{definition}
A condition in ${\mathbb{P}}$ is a tuple $p= \langle  g,f, H, F     \rangle$ where:
\begin{enumerate}
\item ${\operatorname{dom}}(g)$ is a finite subset of $\eta$ and ${\operatorname{dom}}(H)=\eta \setminus {\operatorname{dom}}(g),$

\item For each $\xi \in {\operatorname{dom}}(g), g(\xi) \in B_\xi,$

\item For $\zeta < \xi$ in ${\operatorname{dom}}(g), g(\zeta) \prec g(\xi),$ i.e., $g(\zeta) \subseteq g(\xi)$ and $otp(g(\zeta)) < \kappa_{g(\xi)}$,

\item If $\xi > \max({\operatorname{dom}}(g)),$ then $H(\xi) \in U_\xi, H(\xi) \subseteq B_\xi,$

\item If $\xi \notin {\operatorname{dom}}(g)$ and $\xi < \max({\operatorname{dom}}(g)),$ then setting $\zeta=\min({\operatorname{dom}}(g) \setminus \xi),$ we have
$H(\xi) \in U^\xi_{\zeta, g(\zeta)}$,

\item If $\xi < \zeta, \xi \in {\operatorname{dom}}(g)$ and $\zeta \notin {\operatorname{dom}}(g),$ then for all $z \in H(\zeta), g(\xi) \prec z,$

\item ${\operatorname{dom}}(f)={\operatorname{dom}}(g),$ and for $\xi \in {\operatorname{dom}}(f)$:
\begin{enumerate}
\item [(7-1)] If  $\xi < \max({\operatorname{dom}}(f)),$ then setting $\zeta=\min({\operatorname{dom}}(f)\setminus \xi),$
we have $f(\xi) \in {\operatorname{Col}}((\kappa_{g(\xi)})_*^{++}, < \kappa_{g(\zeta)})$,

\item [(7-2)] If $\xi = \max({\operatorname{dom}}(f)),$ then $f(\xi) \in {\operatorname{Col}}((\kappa_{g(\xi)})_*^{++}, < \kappa),$
\end{enumerate}
\item ${\operatorname{dom}}(F)={\operatorname{dom}}(H)$,

\item For $\xi \in {\operatorname{dom}}(F), F(\xi)$ is a function with domain $H(\xi)$, and for $y \in H(\xi)$
\begin{enumerate}
\item [(9-1)] If $\xi < \max({\operatorname{dom}}(g))$, then setting $\zeta=\min({\operatorname{dom}}(g)\setminus \xi)$ and $x=g(\zeta),$
we have $F(\xi)(y) \in {\operatorname{Col}}((\kappa_y)_*^{++}, < \kappa_x)$ and $[\bar{F}(\xi)]_{U^\xi_{\zeta,x}} \in K^\xi_{\zeta,x},$
where $\bar{F}(\xi)$ is defined on $P_{\kappa_x}(otp(x \cap \kappa_\xi))$ by  $\bar{y} \mapsto F(\xi)(y)$ (where $\bar{y}=\{ otp(x \cap \eta): \eta \in y  \}$),


\item [(9-2)] If $\xi > \max({\operatorname{dom}}(g)),$ then $F(\xi)(y) \in {\operatorname{Col}}((\kappa_y)_*^{++}, <\kappa)$ and $[F(\xi)]_{U_\xi} \in K_\xi.$

\end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}
\end{definition}

nexttext:
We call $\langle  g^p, f^p  \rangle$ the stem of $p$, and denote it by $stem(p)$.
The following definition will be used later.
\begin{definition}
The pair $\langle  g, f  \rangle$ is a ${\mathbb{P}}$-stem, if there exists $p\in {\mathbb{P}}$ such that $stem(p)=\langle  g, f  \rangle $
\end{definition}
We now define the order relation.  In fact we define two kind of order relations $\leq$ and $\leq^*$.
\begin{definition}
Let $p, q \in {\mathbb{P}}.$

$(a)$ $p \leq q$ ($p$ is an extension of $q$) iff
\begin{enumerate}
\item $g^p \supseteq g^q,$

\item $\xi \in {\operatorname{dom}}(g^p) \setminus {\operatorname{dom}}(g^q) \Rightarrow g^p(\xi) \in H^q(\xi),$

\item If $\xi \notin {\operatorname{dom}}(g^p),$ then $H^p(\xi) \subseteq H^q(\xi),$

\item If $\xi \in {\operatorname{dom}}(f^q)$ and $\xi < \max({\operatorname{dom}}(f^p)),$ then setting $\zeta=\min({\operatorname{dom}}(f^p \setminus \xi))$, we have
$f^p(\xi) \leq f^q(\xi) \upharpoonright \kappa_{g^p(\zeta)}$,

\item If $\xi=\max({\operatorname{dom}}(f^q)),$ then $f^p(\xi) \leq f^q(\xi),$

\item If $\xi \in {\operatorname{dom}}(f^p) \setminus {\operatorname{dom}}(f^q),$ then setting $\zeta=\min({\operatorname{dom}}(f^p \setminus \xi))$, we have
$f^p(\xi) \leq F^q(\xi)(g^p(\xi)) \upharpoonright \kappa_{g^p(\beta)}$,

\item If $\xi \in {\operatorname{dom}}(f^p) \setminus {\operatorname{dom}}(f^q)$ and $\xi=\max({\operatorname{dom}}(f^p)),$ then $f^p(\xi) \leq F^q(\xi)(g^p(\xi)),$

\item If $\max({\operatorname{dom}}(g^p)) < \xi,$ then for each $y \in H^p(\xi), F^p(\xi)(y) \leq F^q(\xi)(y),$

\item If $\xi \notin {\operatorname{dom}}(g^p)$ and $\xi < \max({\operatorname{dom}}(g^p)),$ then setting $\zeta=\min({\operatorname{dom}}(g^p)\setminus \xi),$ for each $y \in H^p(\xi)$
we have $F^p(\xi)(y) \leq F^q(\xi)(y) \upharpoonright \kappa_{g^p(\zeta)}$.
\end{enumerate}

$(b)$ $p \leq^* q$ ($p$ is a Prikry or a direct extension of $q$) iff $p \leq q$ and ${\operatorname{dom}}(g^p)={\operatorname{dom}}(g^q).$
\end{definition}
Let's state the main properties of the forcing notion ${\mathbb{P}}.$ Let $G$ be ${\mathbb{P}}$-generic over $V[H]$, and let $g^*=\bigcup_{p\in G}g^p.$
\begin{lemma}
(Basic properties of the forcing notion ${\mathbb{P}}$)

\begin{enumerate}
\item [(a)] ${\mathbb{P}}$ satisfies the $\kappa_\eta^+$-c.c..

\item [(b)] $g^*$ is a function with domain $\eta.$

\item [(c)] For $\xi<\eta$ set $x^*_\xi=g^*(\xi)$ and $\tau_\xi=\kappa_{x^*_\xi}=x^*_\xi \cap \kappa.$ Then $\kappa_\eta=\bigcup_{\xi<\eta}x^*_\xi$
and $\kappa=\sup_{\xi<\eta}\tau_\xi.$
\end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}
We now state a factorization property of ${\mathbb{P}}.$ Assume $p \in {\mathbb{P}}$ with $g^p=\{ \langle \alpha, x \rangle \},$ where $\alpha < \eta$ is a limit ordinal.
For $\xi < \alpha$ let $v_\xi=\bar{U}^\xi_{\alpha,x}$. Also for $\xi < \zeta < \alpha$ let $y \mapsto \bar{v}^\xi_{\zeta,y}$ be such that
$v_\xi=[y \mapsto \bar{v}^\xi_{\zeta,y}]_{v_\zeta}$, where each $\bar{v}^\xi_{\zeta,y}$
is a normal measure on $P_{\kappa_x \cap y}(otp(\kappa_x \cap y))$. Also let $v^\xi_{\zeta,y}$ be the lift of
$\bar{v}^\xi_{\zeta,y}$ on $P_{\kappa_x \cap y}(\kappa_x \cap y)$.
Also we can find the sets $b_\xi \subseteq \overline{H(\xi)}, b_\xi \in v_\xi,$ such that for all $\zeta < \gamma < \xi< \alpha$ and
 all $y \in b_\xi, \bar{v}^{\zeta}_{\xi,y}=[z \mapsto \bar{v}^{\zeta}_{\gamma, z}]_{v^{\gamma}_{\xi,y}}$.
Also let $k_\xi=K^\xi_{\alpha,x}.$
\begin{lemma}
(The factorization property)
With the same notation as above, the forcing notion ${\mathbb{P}} / p$ can be factored as ${\mathbb{P}}_0 \times {\mathbb{P}}_1,$
where
\begin{enumerate}
\item ${\mathbb{P}}_0$ is defined using:
\begin{itemize}
\item The normal measures $v_\xi=\bar{U}^\xi_{\alpha,x}, \xi < \alpha,$
\item The sets $b_\xi, \xi < \alpha,$
\item The functions $y \mapsto \bar{v}^\xi_{\zeta,y},$ for $\xi < \zeta < \alpha,$
\item The generic filters $k_\xi, \xi < \alpha.$
\end{itemize}
\item ${\mathbb{P}}_1$ is defined using:
\begin{itemize}
\item The normal measures $U_\xi, \alpha < \xi < \eta,$
\item The sets $H(\xi), \alpha < \xi < \eta,$
\item The functions $x \mapsto \bar{U}^\xi_{\zeta,x},$ for $\alpha < \xi < \zeta < \eta,$
\item The generic filters $K_\xi, \alpha < \xi < \eta.$
\end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}

With the same notation as above, forcing with ${\mathbb{P}}_0$ adds a generic sequence $\langle   y_\xi: \xi<\alpha   \rangle$ such that $y_\xi \in P_{\kappa_x}(\kappa_x^{+\xi})$
and $\bigcup_{\xi<\alpha}y_\xi=\kappa_x^{+\alpha}.$ As $otp(x)=\kappa_x^{+\alpha},$ so using the resulting order isomorphism,
we can lift this chain to get a sequence $\langle   y^*_\xi: \xi<\alpha   \rangle,$ with $y^*_\xi \in P_{\kappa_x}(x \cap \kappa^{+\xi})$ whose union
is $x$. Setting $\tau^*_\xi=y_\xi \cap \kappa_x,$ we have  $\tau^*_\xi=y^*_\xi \cap \kappa=\tau_\xi$ and forcing with ${\mathbb{P}}_0$ collapses cardinals between $(\tau_\xi)_*^{++}$ and $\tau_{\xi+1}$ for each $\xi<\alpha.$

In general, if $p\in {\mathbb{P}}$ is such that ${\operatorname{dom}}(g^p)$ has size $n$, then we can factor ${\mathbb{P}}/p$ as the product of $n+1$ forcings as above.
\begin{lemma} (Prikry property)
\begin{enumerate}





\item [(a)]  $({\mathbb{P}}, \leq, \leq^*)$ satisfies the Prikry property.

\item [(b)] Let $p\in {\mathbb{P}}, \alpha \in {\operatorname{dom}}(g^p)$ where $\alpha$ is a limit ordinal and let $\phi$ be a statement in the forcing language.
Then there is a condition $p' \leq^* p$ such that if $q \leq p$ and $q$ decides $\phi,$ then $q \upharpoonright \alpha^{\frown} p'\upharpoonright [\alpha, \eta)$
decides $\phi$ in the same way.
\end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}
Using the above lemmas, and by standard arguments, we  get the following.
\begin{lemma}
(Preservation of cardinals)
\begin{enumerate}
\item [(a)] $\kappa$ is preserved and has cofinality $cf(\eta)$ in the generic extension.

\item [(b)] All cardinals and cofinalities below $\tau_0$ are preserved.

\item [(c)] Let $\tau$ be a cardinal in $V$ with $\tau_\alpha < \tau < \tau_{\alpha}^{+\alpha+1},$ for $\alpha$ limit. Then $|\tau|^{V[H][G]}=\tau_\alpha.$

\item [(d)] Cardinals between $\kappa$ and $\kappa_\eta=\kappa^{+\eta}$ are collapsed and $\kappa^+_{V[H][G]}=\kappa^{+\eta+1}_{V[H]}=\kappa_\eta^+.$

\item [(e)] For each $\alpha < \eta,$ the cardinals between $(\tau_\alpha)_*^{++}$ and $\tau_{\alpha+1}$ are collapsed.

\item [(f)] Let $\tau<\kappa$ be a cardinal in $V$  such that for some  ordinal $\alpha < \eta, \tau_\alpha' \leq \tau \leq (\tau_\alpha)_*^{++}$, where
for successor $\alpha, \tau_\alpha'=\tau_\alpha$ and for limit $\alpha, \tau_\alpha'=\tau_{\alpha}^{+\alpha+1}.$
Then $\tau$ is preserved.
\end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}

\begin{lemma}
(The factorization property)
With the same notation as above, the forcing notion ${\mathbb{P}} / p$ can be factored as ${\mathbb{P}}_0 \times {\mathbb{P}}_1,$
where
\begin{enumerate}
\item ${\mathbb{P}}_0$ is defined using:
\begin{itemize}
\item The normal measures $v_\xi=\bar{U}^\xi_{\alpha,x}, \xi < \alpha,$
\item The sets $b_\xi, \xi < \alpha,$
\item The functions $y \mapsto \bar{v}^\xi_{\zeta,y},$ for $\xi < \zeta < \alpha,$
\item The generic filters $k_\xi, \xi < \alpha.$
\end{itemize}
\item ${\mathbb{P}}_1$ is defined using:
\begin{itemize}
\item The normal measures $U_\xi, \alpha < \xi < \eta,$
\item The sets $H(\xi), \alpha < \xi < \eta,$
\item The functions $x \mapsto \bar{U}^\xi_{\zeta,x},$ for $\alpha < \xi < \zeta < \eta,$
\item The generic filters $K_\xi, \alpha < \xi < \eta.$
\end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}

With the same notation as above, forcing with ${\mathbb{P}}_0$ adds a generic sequence $\langle   y_\xi: \xi<\alpha   \rangle$ such that $y_\xi \in P_{\kappa_x}(\kappa_x^{+\xi})$
and $\bigcup_{\xi<\alpha}y_\xi=\kappa_x^{+\alpha}.$ As $otp(x)=\kappa_x^{+\alpha},$ so using the resulting order isomorphism,
we can lift this chain to get a sequence $\langle   y^*_\xi: \xi<\alpha   \rangle,$ with $y^*_\xi \in P_{\kappa_x}(x \cap \kappa^{+\xi})$ whose union
is $x$. Setting $\tau^*_\xi=y_\xi \cap \kappa_x,$ we have  $\tau^*_\xi=y^*_\xi \cap \kappa=\tau_\xi$ and forcing with ${\mathbb{P}}_0$ collapses cardinals between $(\tau_\xi)_*^{++}$ and $\tau_{\xi+1}$ for each $\xi<\alpha.$

In general, if $p\in {\mathbb{P}}$ is such that ${\operatorname{dom}}(g^p)$ has size $n$, then we can factor ${\mathbb{P}}/p$ as the product of $n+1$ forcings as above.
\begin{lemma} (Prikry property)
\begin{enumerate}





\item [(a)]  $({\mathbb{P}}, \leq, \leq^*)$ satisfies the Prikry property.

\item [(b)] Let $p\in {\mathbb{P}}, \alpha \in {\operatorname{dom}}(g^p)$ where $\alpha$ is a limit ordinal and let $\phi$ be a statement in the forcing language.
Then there is a condition $p' \leq^* p$ such that if $q \leq p$ and $q$ decides $\phi,$ then $q \upharpoonright \alpha^{\frown} p'\upharpoonright [\alpha, \eta)$
decides $\phi$ in the same way.
\end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}
Using the above lemmas, and by standard arguments, we  get the following.
\begin{lemma}
(Preservation of cardinals)
\begin{enumerate}
\item [(a)] $\kappa$ is preserved and has cofinality $cf(\eta)$ in the generic extension.

\item [(b)] All cardinals and cofinalities below $\tau_0$ are preserved.

\item [(c)] Let $\tau$ be a cardinal in $V$ with $\tau_\alpha < \tau < \tau_{\alpha}^{+\alpha+1},$ for $\alpha$ limit. Then $|\tau|^{V[H][G]}=\tau_\alpha.$

\item [(d)] Cardinals between $\kappa$ and $\kappa_\eta=\kappa^{+\eta}$ are collapsed and $\kappa^+_{V[H][G]}=\kappa^{+\eta+1}_{V[H]}=\kappa_\eta^+.$

\item [(e)] For each $\alpha < \eta,$ the cardinals between $(\tau_\alpha)_*^{++}$ and $\tau_{\alpha+1}$ are collapsed.

\item [(f)] Let $\tau<\kappa$ be a cardinal in $V$  such that for some  ordinal $\alpha < \eta, \tau_\alpha' \leq \tau \leq (\tau_\alpha)_*^{++}$, where
for successor $\alpha, \tau_\alpha'=\tau_\alpha$ and for limit $\alpha, \tau_\alpha'=\tau_{\alpha}^{+\alpha+1}.$
Then $\tau$ is preserved.
\end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}

Let $\mu \in j^*(I)$ be such that $\sup j''\kappa_\eta^+ < \mu < j(\kappa_\eta^+).$ By elementarity, for all $\alpha \in I$
we can find $\xi_\alpha, \delta_\alpha < \kappa$ and $r_\alpha =(p_\alpha, d_\alpha) \in j^*({\mathbb{R}})$
with ${\operatorname{dom}}(g^{p_\alpha})=\vec{\gamma}$
such that $r_\alpha \Vdash$`` $\langle j(\alpha), \xi_\alpha \rangle <_{j^*({\smash{\underset{\raisebox{1.2pt}[0cm][0cm]{$\sim$}} {{{T}}}}})} \langle \mu, \delta_\alpha \rangle$''.

By simple counting arguments, and the fact that ${\mathbb{C}}'$ does not add any new sequences of length $\kappa_{\gamma_0},$
we can conclude that there is a cofinal subset $J \subseteq I, J \in V[H^*]$, fixed ordinals
$\xi, \delta< \kappa$ and a fixed $\langle \langle \bar{g}, \bar{f}, \bar{H}, \bar{F}  \rangle, \bar{d} \rangle$
such that for all $\alpha \in J, \xi_\alpha=\xi, \delta_\alpha=\delta$
and $r_\alpha \upharpoonright (\gamma_0+1)= \langle \langle \bar{g}, \bar{f}, \bar{H}, \bar{F}  \rangle, \bar{d} \rangle$.
Note that for any such $\alpha, stem(r_\alpha)= \langle \bar{g}, \bar{f}, \bar{d} \rangle.$

Then for all $\alpha < \beta$ in $J$, there is a condition $r \in j^*({\mathbb{R}})$ with
$stem(r)= \langle \bar{g}, \bar{f}, \bar{d} \rangle$ and $r \upharpoonright (\gamma_0+1)= \langle \langle \bar{g}, \bar{f}, \bar{H}, \bar{F}  \rangle, \bar{d} \rangle$
such that
 $r \Vdash$`` $\langle j(\alpha), \xi \rangle <_{j^*({\smash{\underset{\raisebox{1.2pt}[0cm][0cm]{$\sim$}} {{{T}}}}})} \langle j(\beta), \xi \rangle$''. Since
 $j^*( \langle \langle \bar{g}, \bar{f}, \bar{H}, \bar{F}  \rangle, \bar{d} \rangle)= \langle \langle \bar{g}, \bar{f}, \bar{H}, \bar{F}  \rangle, \bar{d} \rangle,$ by elementarity,
 there is a condition $r \in {\mathbb{R}}$
 such that  $stem(r)= \langle \bar{g}, \bar{f}, \bar{d} \rangle,$  $r \upharpoonright (\gamma_0+1)= \langle \langle \bar{g}, \bar{f}, \bar{H}, \bar{F}  \rangle, \bar{d} \rangle$
and $r \Vdash$`` $\langle \alpha, \xi \rangle <_{{\smash{\underset{\raisebox{1.2pt}[0cm][0cm]{$\sim$}} {{{T}}}}}} \langle \beta, \xi \rangle$''.

Let $\rho=\min(J).$ For every $\alpha \in (L \setminus \rho) \setminus J$ let $\alpha'=\min(J\setminus \alpha)$
and let $\Lambda^*_\alpha \in \Xi_{\gamma+1}$ be such that $\Lambda^*_\alpha \upharpoonright \gamma_0=\Lambda_0, stem(\Lambda^*_\alpha)=stem(\Lambda_0)$ and $\Lambda^*_\alpha \Vdash^*$`` $\langle \alpha, \epsilon \rangle <_{{\smash{\underset{\raisebox{1.2pt}[0cm][0cm]{$\sim$}} {{{T}}}}}}      \langle \alpha', \epsilon  \rangle$''. We can find such
a $\Lambda^*_\alpha$ by our assumption
$\Lambda_0 \Vdash^*$``$u_\alpha <_{{\smash{\underset{\raisebox{1.2pt}[0cm][0cm]{$\sim$}} {{{T}}}}}} u_{\alpha'}$''.

Let $\alpha \in L \setminus \rho.$ If $\alpha \in J$ define $\Lambda_\alpha =\Lambda^*_\alpha.$
If $\alpha \notin J,$ then set $\Lambda_\alpha=\Lambda^*_{\alpha'}  \wedge \Lambda^*.$
Then $\rho$ and $\langle   \Lambda_\alpha: \alpha \in L \setminus \rho        \rangle$
are as required.
\end{proof}
\begin{lemma}
There are $\rho< \kappa_\eta^+$ and conditions $\langle p_\alpha: \alpha \in J \setminus \rho     \rangle$
with $p_\alpha \upharpoonright \gamma_0+1 = \langle \langle \bar{g}, \bar{f}, \bar{H}, \bar{F}  \rangle, \bar{d} \rangle$
such that for all $\alpha < \beta$ in $J \setminus \rho, p_\alpha \wedge p_\beta \Vdash$``$u_\alpha <_{{\smash{\underset{\raisebox{1.2pt}[0cm][0cm]{$\sim$}} {{{T}}}}}} u_\beta$''.
Here $ p_\alpha \wedge p_\beta $ denotes the weakest extension of $p_\alpha$ and $p_\beta.$
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
Let $\Pi= \langle \langle \bar{g}, \bar{f}, \bar{H}, \bar{F}  \rangle, \bar{d} \rangle.$
We define sequences $\langle \rho_\xi: \gamma_0 < \xi< \eta   \rangle$ and $\langle \Lambda^\xi_\alpha: \alpha \in J \setminus \rho_\xi,   \gamma_0 < \xi< \eta     \rangle$ by induction on $\xi$ such that for all such $\xi:$
\begin{enumerate}
\item [$(1)_\xi$:] For all $\alpha \in J \setminus \rho_\xi, \Lambda^\xi_\alpha \in \Xi_{\xi}$,

\item [$(2)_\xi$:] For all $\zeta < \xi$ and all $\alpha \in J \setminus \rho_\xi$ we have $\Lambda^\xi_\alpha \upharpoonright \zeta = \Lambda^\zeta_\alpha,$
\item [$(3)_\xi$:] For all $\alpha < \beta$ in $J \setminus \rho_{\xi+1}$, for all $\Lambda^* \in \Xi_{\xi+1}$ with $stem(\Lambda^*)$
extending $stem(\Pi)$ with $\max({\operatorname{dom}}(g_{\Lambda^*}))=\xi,$ if $\Lambda^*$ is compatible with $\Lambda^{\xi+1}_\alpha$
and $\Lambda^{\xi+1}_\beta,$
then $\Lambda^* \Vdash^*$``$u_\alpha <_{{\smash{\underset{\raisebox{1.2pt}[0cm][0cm]{$\sim$}} {{{T}}}}}} u_\beta$''.
\end{enumerate}

For $\xi=\gamma_0+1$ set $\rho_{\gamma_0+1}=0$ and $\Lambda^{\gamma_0+1}_\alpha=\Pi,$ for all $\alpha \in J.$

For limit $\xi > \gamma_0$ set $\rho_\xi=\sup_{\gamma_0 < \zeta < \xi} \rho_\zeta,$
and for $\alpha \in J \setminus \rho_\xi$ let $\Lambda^\xi_\alpha$ be the unique element of $\Xi_\xi$
such that for all $\gamma_0 < \zeta < \xi, \Lambda^\xi_\alpha \upharpoonright \zeta = \Lambda^\zeta_\alpha.$
Note that this is well-defined by assumptions $(2)_\zeta, \gamma_0 < \zeta < \xi.$
Clearly $(1)_\xi$ and $(2)_\xi$ are satisfied and there is noting to prove related to $(3)_\xi$.

Now suppose that we have defined $\langle \rho_\zeta: \gamma_0 < \zeta \leq \xi \rangle $ and $ \langle \Lambda^\zeta_\alpha: \alpha \in J \setminus \rho_\zeta, \gamma_0 < \zeta \leq \xi  \rangle.$ We define $\rho_{\xi+1}$ and
$ \langle \Lambda^{\xi+1}_\alpha: \alpha \in J \setminus \rho_{\xi+1} \rangle.$

extends $stem(\Pi)$ and $\Lambda $ is compatible with $\Lambda^{\varsigma}_\alpha, \gamma_0< \varsigma \leq \zeta$.

Finally set $\rho=\sup_{\gamma_0 < \xi < \eta} \rho_\xi < \kappa_\eta^+$

 \begin{itemize}
 \item $stem(p_\alpha)=stem(\Pi),$

 \item For all $\xi$ with $\gamma_0 < \xi < \eta, \xi \in {\operatorname{dom}}(H^{p_\alpha})$,

is such that $stem(\Lambda^*)$ extends $stem(\Pi)$ with $\max({\operatorname{dom}}(g_{\Lambda^*}))=\xi.$ Also assume that $\Lambda^*$ is compatible with $\Lambda^{\xi+1}_\alpha$
and $\Lambda^{\xi+1}_\beta.$ Consider $\Lambda = \Lambda^* \upharpoonright \xi.$
Then $\Lambda$ fits both $\alpha$ and $\beta,$ so by our construction and Lemma 3.19, we can easily conclude that

Finally set $\rho=\sup_{\gamma_0 < \xi < \eta} \rho_\xi < \kappa_\eta^+$
 and for each $\alpha \in J \setminus \rho$ let $p_\alpha$ be the unique condition
 obtained using the sequence $\langle  \Lambda^\xi_\alpha: \gamma_0 < \xi < \eta           \rangle$. So

 \item $stem(p_\alpha)=stem(\Pi),$
 \item $p_\alpha \upharpoonright \gamma_0+1= \Pi,$

\end{itemize}

If $q \leq p_\alpha \wedge p_\beta$,
 then by construction $stem(q) \Vdash^*$``$u_\alpha <_{{\smash{\underset{\raisebox{1.2pt}[0cm][0cm]{$\sim$}} {{{T}}}}}} u_\beta$'', so
$q \nVdash$``$u_\alpha \nless_{{\smash{\underset{\raisebox{1.2pt}[0cm][0cm]{$\sim$}} {{{T}}}}}} u_\beta$''. It follows that $p_\alpha \wedge p_\beta \Vdash$``$u_\alpha <_{{\smash{\underset{\raisebox{1.2pt}[0cm][0cm]{$\sim$}} {{{T}}}}}} u_\beta$''.
The lemma follows.
\end{proof}






The rest of the argument is standard.  Let $\langle p_\alpha: \alpha \in J \setminus \rho     \rangle$ be as in the above Lemma.
We want to find a condition $q$ that forces that the set $\{\alpha \in J: p_\alpha\in G\}$ is unbounded in $\kappa_\eta^+$, since such a $q$ forces that there is a branch in ${\smash{\underset{\raisebox{1.2pt}[0cm][0cm]{$\sim$}} {{{T}}}}}$, namely, the downward closure of $\{\langle \alpha , \epsilon \rangle : p_\alpha \in G\}$.

Assume that this is not the case. So, it is forced that the set $\{\alpha \in J : p_\alpha \in G\}$ is bounded. Since ${\mathbb{R}}$ is $\kappa_\eta^+$-c.c., in $V[H]$, there is an ordinal $\beta < \kappa_\eta^+$ such that it is forced by the trivial condition that $\{\alpha : p_\alpha \in G\}\subseteq \beta$. This is impossible, as for any $\gamma \in J \setminus \beta$, $p_\gamma$ forces the opposite statement.

This completes the proof of the theorem in the case $\eta < \kappa_0$.
We now consider the general case. Fix the sequence $\langle \kappa_\xi: \xi \leq \eta     \rangle$
as before. As $\eta < \kappa_\eta,$ we can find the least $\xi_* < \eta$
such that $\kappa_{\xi_*-1} \leq\eta < \kappa_{\xi_*}$, where $\kappa_{-1}=\omega$. Note that we can assume that $\xi_* >0.$
 We consider two cases:
 \begin{enumerate}
 \item $\eta > \kappa_{\xi_*-1}:$ Then by the same arguments as above, we can find a generic extension in which cardinals below $\kappa_{\xi_*-1}$
 are preserved, and $\kappa_\eta^+$ is the successor of the limit of the first $\eta - \kappa_{\xi_*-1}$
 measurable cardinals above $\kappa_{\xi_*-1}$ which has the tree property.
 But then $\kappa_\eta^+$ is the successor of the limit of the first $\eta$
 measurable cardinals and it has the tree property.

 \item $\eta = \kappa_{\xi_*-1}:$ Then $\eta - \xi_* =\eta,$ so again by the same arguments as above we can find a generic extension in which
 $\kappa_{\xi_*}$ changes its cofinality to $\eta, \kappa_\eta^+$ becomes the new successor of $\kappa_{\xi_*}$,
 $\kappa_{\xi_*}$ is the limit of the first $\eta$ measurable cardinals and $\kappa_\eta^+$ has the tree property.
 \end{enumerate}
 The theorem follows.
\hfill$\Box$
\begin{remark}
By the same argument, we can prove the following: Assume $\lambda$ is a singular limit of $\eta$ supercompact cardinals, where $\eta \leq \lambda$
is a limit ordinal. Then there is a generic extension in which $\lambda^+=\aleph_{\eta^2+1},$ and the tree property holds at $\aleph_{\eta^2+1}.$
\end{remark}
\begin{remark}
By a result of Neeman \cite{neeman0}, it is consistent, relative to some large cardinals, that for some singular cardinal $\kappa$
 of countable cofinality, $SCH$ fails at $\kappa$ and tree property holds at $\kappa^+$. Sinapova \cite{sinapova3} proved the same result for
 $\kappa=\aleph_{\omega^2}.$ She also proved similar result for a singular cardinal of uncountable cofinality \cite{sinapova2}.
By working harder, it is also possible to combine the ideas of the above proof with those of Sinapova \cite{sinapova3}, to get the following:
Assume $\lambda$ is a singular limit of $\eta$ supercompact cardinals, where $\eta \leq \lambda$
is a limit ordinal. Then there is a generic extension in which $\lambda^+=\aleph_{\eta^2+1}, \aleph_{\eta^2}$ is a strong limit cardinal,  $2^{\aleph_{\eta^2}} > \aleph_{\eta^2+1}$ (and so $SCH$ fails at $\aleph_{\eta^2}$) and the tree property holds at $\aleph_{\eta^2+1}.$

\end{remark}


\section{Product of Levy collapses}
In this section we present another proof of our main theorem, using  ideas of Neeman \cite{neeman}. The idea of using Neeman's method to prove the theorem was suggested by Yair Hayut \cite{hayut}.  The proof is much easier than the proof given in the previous section.
However let us mention that the method given in this section can not be used to get the result stated in Remark 3.22.
 Let $\langle  \kappa_\xi: \xi \leq \eta      \rangle$
be an increasing and continuous sequence of cardinals so that:
\begin{enumerate}
\item Each $\kappa_\xi,$ where $\xi=0$ or $\xi$ is a successor ordinal is a supercompact cardinal,
\item $\kappa_\eta=\lambda.$
\item If $\xi=0$ or $\xi$ is a successor ordinal, then  $\kappa_\xi$ is Laver indestructible under $\kappa_\xi$-directed closed forcing notions,
\item For all $\xi \leq \eta, 2^{\kappa_\xi}=\kappa_{\xi}^+.$
\end{enumerate}
As before we can assume that
$\eta<\kappa_0$.






Let $\mathbb{C}$ be the Easton support iteration of ${\operatorname{Col}}((\kappa_i)_*^{++}, < \kappa_{i+1}), i<\eta,$ and let $H$ be $\mathbb{C}$-generic over $V$. The following lemma can be proved easily:
\begin{lemma}
$(a)$ $\mathbb{C}$ is $\kappa$-directed closed, in particular $\kappa$ remains supercompact in $V[H].$

$(b)$ In $V[H]$, the only measurable cardinals in the interval $(\kappa, \kappa_\eta)$ are $(\kappa_i)_*, i<\eta$ and $\kappa_\eta$ is the limit of them; in particular,
$\kappa_\eta$ is the limit of the first $\eta$ measurable cardinals above $\kappa.$

$(c)$ $NSP(\kappa_\eta^+)$ holds in $V[H].$
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
$(a)$ and $(b)$ are clear; for $(c),$ see \cite{LambieHanson2015}.
\end{proof}
The following lemma completes the proof.
\begin{lemma}
Work in $V[H]$. There is $\mu < \kappa$ such that in the generic extension of $V[H]$
by ${\operatorname{Col}}(\omega, \mu) \times {\operatorname{Col}}(\mu^{+}, \kappa)$ the tree property at $\kappa_{\eta}^+$ holds.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}

Assume that for all $\mu < \kappa$ the forcing ${\operatorname{Col}}(\omega,\mu)\times{\operatorname{Col}}(\mu^{+},\kappa)$ adds an Aronszajn tree at $\kappa_\eta^+$ and let ${\smash{\underset{\raisebox{1.2pt}[0cm][0cm]{$\sim$}} {{{T}}}}}_\mu$ be a name for this tree.

Let $j\colon V[H] \to M$ be a $\kappa_\eta^+$-supercompact elementary embedding, i.e., ${\operatorname{crit}}(j) = \kappa$ and $M$ is closed under $\kappa_\eta^+$-sequences.
Let $\vec{T}=\langle {\smash{\underset{\raisebox{1.2pt}[0cm][0cm]{$\sim$}} {{{T}}}}}_\mu: \mu<\kappa \rangle$ and set
$j(\vec{T})= \langle {\smash{\underset{\raisebox{1.2pt}[0cm][0cm]{$\sim$}} {{{T}}}}}^*_\mu: \mu<j(\kappa) \rangle.$



In $M$, let us pick $\mu = \kappa_\eta < j(\kappa)$, so ${\smash{\underset{\raisebox{1.2pt}[0cm][0cm]{$\sim$}} {{{T}}}}}^*_{\kappa_\eta}$ is a ${\operatorname{Col}}(\omega, \kappa_\eta)\times {\operatorname{Col}}(\kappa_\eta^{+},j(\kappa))$-name for an Aronszajn tree at $j(\kappa_\eta^+)$. Let $\delta = \sup j''(\kappa_\eta^+) < j(\kappa_\eta^+)$. By recursion on $\alpha < \kappa_\eta^+$, and using the
$\kappa_\eta^{+}$-closure of ${\operatorname{Col}}^M(\kappa_\eta^{+},j(\kappa))$,
 pick a sequence  $\langle (p_\alpha, q_\alpha): \alpha < \kappa_\eta^+ \rangle$ such that:
\begin{enumerate}
\item $(p_\alpha, q_\alpha)\in{\operatorname{Col}}(\omega,\kappa_\eta) \times {\operatorname{Col}}^M(\kappa_\eta^+,j(\kappa))),$

\item $\langle q_\alpha: \alpha < \kappa_\eta^+ \rangle$ is a decreasing sequence in ${\operatorname{Col}}^M(\kappa_\eta^+,j(\kappa)))$,

\item There is an ordinal $\zeta_\alpha < j(\kappa_\eta)$ such that $(p_\alpha,q_\alpha)\Vdash \langle j(\alpha),\zeta_\alpha\rangle \leq_{{\smash{\underset{\raisebox{1.2pt}[0cm][0cm]{$\sim$}} {{{T}}}}}^*_{\kappa_\eta}} \langle \delta, 0\rangle$.

\end{enumerate}
Let $I\subseteq \kappa_\eta^+$ be a cofinal set such that for all $\alpha\in I$, $p_\alpha = p_\star$ and $\zeta_\alpha < j(\kappa_{\sigma})$ for some fixed $p_\star\in{\operatorname{Col}}(\omega,\kappa_\eta)$ and $\sigma < \eta$.

For every $\alpha, \beta\in I$, $\alpha < \beta$, $M$ satisfies that there is a condition $r = (p_\star, q_\beta)$ and ordinals $\zeta_\alpha, \zeta_\beta < j(\kappa_\sigma)$ such that that $r$ forces $\langle j(\alpha), \zeta_\alpha\rangle \leq_{{\smash{\underset{\raisebox{1.2pt}[0cm][0cm]{$\sim$}} {{{T}}}}}^*_{\kappa_\eta}} \langle j(\beta), \zeta_\beta\rangle$. Reflecting this downwards (for every pair $\alpha, \beta$ separately), in $V[H]$ there is $\rho < \kappa$, a condition $r$ and $\zeta, \eta < \kappa_\sigma$ such that $r\Vdash \langle \alpha, \zeta\rangle \leq_{{\smash{\underset{\raisebox{1.2pt}[0cm][0cm]{$\sim$}} {{{T}}}}}_\rho} \langle \beta, \eta\rangle$. This defines a narrow system on $I$ of width $\kappa_\sigma$ and $\kappa$ relations. Namely, for a pair of ordinal $\rho < \kappa$ and condition $r\in{\operatorname{Col}}(\omega,\rho)\times{\operatorname{Col}}(\rho^+,\kappa)$ we say that $\langle \alpha, \zeta\rangle \leq_{\langle \rho, r\rangle} \langle \beta, \eta\rangle$ iff $r\Vdash \langle \alpha, \zeta\rangle \leq_{{\smash{\underset{\raisebox{1.2pt}[0cm][0cm]{$\sim$}} {{{T}}}}}_\rho} \langle \beta, \eta\rangle$.

A branch in this narrow system consists of a single condition that forces a branch through a name of an Aronszajn tree. Since the narrow system property holds in $V[H]$, such a branch exists so we get a contradiction.
\end{proof}
\begin{remark}
By the same argument, we can prove the following: Assume $\lambda$ is a singular limit of $\eta$ supercompact cardinals, where $\eta \leq \lambda$
is a limit ordinal. Then there is a generic extension in which $\lambda^+=\aleph_{\eta+1},$ and the tree property holds at $\aleph_{\eta+1}.$
\end{remark}
